article_title: Edward Lazear: The Hidden Rot in the Jobs Numbers
article_text:
Most commentators viewed the February jobs report released on March 7 as good news, indicating that the labor market is on a favorable growth path. A more careful reading shows that employment actually fell—as it has in four out of the past six months and in more than one-third of the months during the past two years.

Although it is often overlooked, a key statistic for understanding the labor market is the length of the average workweek. Small changes in the average workweek imply large changes in total hours worked. The...

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Edward Lazear writes that the number of hours worked are declining, resulting in the equivalent of a net loss of 100,000 jobs since September.
twitter.title: The Hidden Rot in the Jobs Numbers

og.title: The Hidden Rot in the Jobs Numbers

article_metadata.author: Edward P. Lazear
article_metadata.article.origheadline: The Hidden Rot in the Jobs Numbers

article_summary:
Although it is often overlooked, a key statistic for understanding the labor market is the length of the average workweek.
Most commentators viewed the February jobs report released on March 7 as good news, indicating that the labor market is on a favorable growth path.
Small changes in the average workweek imply large changes in total hours worked.
A more careful reading shows that employment actually fell—as it has in four out of the past six months and in more than one-third of the months during the past two years.
